Serious question:  how bad is my OCD if I'm worried about, say, $50 of fans lying around from my new computer build.  And that's just a few % of the total cost?
Can you send them back because you don't need them?
Probably not.  The fans I'm talking about will those included either with the case or the CPU cooler
OCD me wants all fans in the case to be the same :P
It's a common medical condition this... f-anxiety.
:ctwokinds-smug:
The cooler part isn't *too* bad, because I could just buy one of a few corsair coolers, and it'd come with some fans that I'd like
But it's the damn cases man. FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF-
Apparently there's no good looking cases that don't come with at least ONE fan.  And most come with 2 - 3, minimum.
1 - 2 intake, 1 exhaust.
yeah, I always found the fans to be the finishing touch to a computer build, the last obsession to satisfy.
I've been thinking about this build for YEARS (yup, obsession problem xD)
And it's come to my attention that RGB is a royal mess.
It is possible to have 1 RGB software controlling everything, but it severely limits choice
Soooooo, I'm considering foregoing it wherever possible :/
Yeah fan control was always a touch/go business I guess the manufacturers just can't collaborate enough to work out a standard.
It's even worse than you think, lol
Every damn motherboard / gpu manufacturer wants you using THEIR RGB ecosystem
And they're not compatible with each other unless you starting doing some non-entry level user shenanigans
I forget what they called it but at one point there was a push to get realtime data from the PSu via a USB jumper or something to the MB.... not sure if that ever came to fruition.
Probably not, since I've just now heard about it
So, RGB is absolutely ridiculous
I forget what company it was, I'll have to look it up. Yeah, too many competing ideologies.
ASUS Aura Sync, MSI Mystic Light, Gigabyte RGB Fusion, Corsair iCUE (they used to have 2 separate softwares that got merged), AsRock, Thermaltake, etc.
Corsair is the odd fan manufacturer out.  Other fan makers with aRGB will support at least ONE of the standards (generally Aura Sync)
But think about this.  Buy a high-end GPU / MOBO, and it's basically guaranteed to have RGB
But if you want the limit how much RGB software you're running, you better match manufacturers
If you have an MSI / ASUS mobo, and an ASUS / MSI GPU, you're gonna need the software from BOTH companies
Suffice to say... I'm kinda pissed off xD
Yeah if they force brand loyalty their entire product line flourishes.
Yeah for us purists, two different apps for the same thing is BLASPHENY!
*M

1 is the $360 MSI Ace (what I was gonna choose before learning about RGB shenanigans)
The other is Gigabyte's $700 extreme overclocking board.  Which is the only one that cools the new chipset entirely passively
Most motherboards are good, as long as the brand is a recognizable one, I've found over the years that you just get more polish and overclocking focus on the top end ones.
Yeah if overclocking is a concern it might be worth something more pricey.
The modern chipsets should mostly be passive, I'm surprised they're not. Is this Intel or AMD?
I know on the Intel side, more and more has been moved OUT of the northbridge chipset over the years.
Hell, the memory controller isn't even in it anymore.
AMD's moving up to PCIe gen 4.  The chipset is putting out a whopping 15W this time
As for overclocking, ironically it's not actually needed, lol
